I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for policy 
and advisory technical assistance (TA) to establish a regulatory framework for urban water 
supply and sanitation. ADB included the TA in the 2013 program of the country operations 
business plan, 2013–2015 for Bangladesh.1  
 
2.  The ADB fact-finding mission during 18–21 November 2012 reached an understanding 
with the government on the TA impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, 
financing arrangements, and outline terms of reference.2 The design and monitoring framework 
is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  In 2010, 81% of the Bangladesh population was supplied with water, compared with the 
global  average  of  89%  and the  South  Asia regional  average  of  90%.3 Although  coverage 
reached 85% in urban areas, access to piped water supply in household premises is provided to 
only 20% of the urban population, requiring significant improvement in service. Of the total 316 
municipalities, only 102 have piped water supply systems, which generally provide intermittent 
daily supply of less than 10 hours.4 Sanitation coverage is lower, with only 57% of the urban 
population  having  access  to  improved  sanitation  facilities  in  2010.  In  the  whole  country, 
wastewater treatment is provided to only a small part of Dhaka. The water supply and sanitation 
(WSS) subsector is plagued with high unaccounted for water (averaging about 25% or more),5 
inadequate  cost  recovery  caused  by  low  tariffs,  limited  utility  autonomy,  and  operating 
inefficiency, resulting in poor service delivery in many urban areas of the country. 
 
4.  The Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives has statutory 
responsibility for WSS, including policy decisions, sectoral budgetary allocation, and evaluation 
and monitoring of policies and projects. The Department of Public Health Engineering and water 
supply and sewerage authorities (WASAs) function under the administrative control of the Local 
Government  Division  (LGD)  of  the  Ministry  of  Local  Government,  Rural  Development  and 
Cooperatives. WASAs are responsible for WSS service provision in Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna, 
and Rajshahi, and municipalities (pourashavas) and city corporations (except for the four cities) 
provide WSS services in their jurisdictions, with technical support from the Department of Public 
Health Engineering. The Policy Support Unit (PSU) was established in 1999 in LGD to lead 
policy development for WSS. 
 
5.  Reforms are needed in two areas: (i) institutional development of water utilities, including 
WASAs, city corporations, and municipalities; and (ii) establishment of a regulatory framework. 
These are heavily intertwined because a regulatory framework cannot usually succeed without 
institutionally developed and more autonomous utilities, and the sustainability of institutionally 
developed utilities will be difficult without an independent regulator. The primary objective of

establishing an economic regulatory framework is to ensure the provision of WSS services in an 
efficient,  transparent,  and  equitable  manner  by  (i)  protecting  the  interests  of  customers,  
(ii)  ensuring  that  customers  receive  the  expected  services,  (iii)  ensuring  that  services  are 
delivered at fair and reasonable tariffs, (iv) ensuring financial sustainability of utilities while 
providing incentives for efficiency, and (v) providing certainty for private sector investments. 
 
6.  The government recognizes the need for a WSS regulator, and a policy condition was 
incorporated in the ongoing ADB-financed sector development program.6 In accordance with the 
condition, the government undertook a study on the most appropriate form for an independent 
water regulator. The study, supported by ADB TA (footnote 6), concluded that the creation of a 
fully mandated regulatory body would be premature because water utilities do not have enough 
autonomy and resources, and their commercial and financial systems are not strong. Instead, 
the regulatory framework can be established in two stages, by first creating a water cell in LGD 
and then an independent water economic regulatory commission (WERC) after 3–5 years. The 
water cell will lead reform initiatives for utilities and prepare sector conditions for establishing the 
WERC  as  outlined  in  the  government’s  Sector  Development  Plan  (FY2011–FY2025).7 In 
January 2011, the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development and Cooperatives issued a 
notification to establish a water cell in the PSU. The water cell needs to be made fully functional 
with  clear  mandates  to  achieve  the  intended  objectives,  for  which  the  government  has 
requested additional support from ADB.8    
 
7.  The TA supports an important government reform agenda for WSS as elaborated in the 
Sector  Development  Plan  (footnote  7).  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2011–2015  for 
Bangladesh recognizes WSS, included in the urban sector, as one of six priority sectors, and 
highlights improvement of the legal and regulatory framework of the urban water subsector.9 
The TA is a follow-on from the ongoing loan and past TA, and is linked with the planned Khilkhet 
Water  Treatment  Plant  Project  in  Dhaka.10 The  establishment  of  an  economic  regulatory 
framework will improve the enabling environment for enhancing public–private partnerships, 
which is being considered in the project. Danida, Denmark’s development cooperation under the 
Ministry of Foreign Affairs, is supporting institutional development of the PSU, including sector 
coordination and policy implementation and monitoring, which complements the TA activities.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
8.  The impact will be a strengthened policy and institutional environment for improved 
urban water supply in Bangladesh. The outcome will be a fully operating water cell with clear 
mandates and necessary tools.

B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
9.  Output 1: Developing adequate rules and standards for regulating and monitoring 
water  utilities  in  the  urban  sector.  This  output  will  support  formulation  of  a  regulatory 
framework for urban water supply and sanitation; the initial focus will be on water supply. Tasks 
include (i) draft financial management regulation, including billing and collection systems, and 
preparation of financial statement; (ii) draft service standards and key performance indicators 
that will be reported by the water utilities and monitored by the water cell; (iii) draft tariff-setting 
and review methodologies to enable independent, transparent, and predictable tariff-setting 
commensurate with service offered, while ensuring financial sustainability of water utilities; (iv) 
draft customer service regulations to protect the interests of customers; (v) develop finance and 
operating reporting requirements for water utilities to the water cell; (vi) recommend, if deemed 
necessary, legislative changes to make water utilities more autonomous to provide an incentive 
for them to improve operating efficiency; and (vii) undertake a study of subsidies to water 
utilities  for  capital  and  operating  expenditures,  resulting  in  recommendations  on  subsidy 
rationalization and an appropriate subsidy mechanism. Service standards and key performance 
indicators define the service obligation of water utilities relating to the provision of water supply 
and sewerage services: they may include hours of supply, residual pressure, drinking water 
quality standards, nonrevenue water, number of staff per 1,000 connections, and operating 
ratios. The water quality monitoring framework, including the scope, parameters to be analyzed, 
and  sampling  and  analysis  methodologies,  will  be  included  to  particularly  address 
microbiological and residual chlorine requirements.   
 
10.  Output 2: Monitoring performance of water utilities. This output will assist the water 
cell in commencing performance monitoring of water utilities by using the rules, regulations, and 
standards  drafted  under  output  1  and  approved  by  the  government.  Tasks  include  
(i) communicate the regulatory framework and reporting requirements to major water utilities, 
such as the WASAs in Dhaka, Chittagong, Khulna, and Rajshahi, and other city corporations 
and large municipalities; (ii) ensure the major water utilities (initial target: five) submit reports in 
conformity  with  the  reporting  requirements;  (iii)  establish  a  database  for  monitoring  the 
performance of utilities; and (iv) prepare the first monitoring report by reviewing and verifying 
submissions  made  by  the  major  water  utilities.  Major  water  utilities  will  be  provided  with 
necessary guidance and advice to ensure the reports submitted are of satisfactory quality. 
 
11.  Output  3:  Initiating  preparation  for  establishing  a  water  economic  regulatory 
commission. Based on an assessment of the progress and achievements made in outputs 1 
and 2, a feasible road map for establishing the full-fledged independent commission will be 
drafted. The organization structure, clear mandates and responsibilities, staff requirements, and 
time-bound actions, among others, will be proposed. The work will involve close consultation 
with all relevant government agencies and other stakeholders.  
 
12.  Output 4: Strengthening the capacity of relevant agencies for implementing the 
regulatory functions. This output will strengthen the capacity of government officers in line 
with their responsibilities. Tasks include (i) assess capacity requirements in accordance with the 
functions of the water cell; (ii) prepare a capacity development program; and (iii) implement the 
capacity development program through classroom training, workshops and seminars, on-the-job 
training, and an exposure visit to a country in Asia where a similar regulatory framework is 
already being practiced successfully. While the main targets of the capacity strengthening will 
be the staff of the water cell, officers of other relevant government agencies and major water 
utilities may also participate in the capacity development program. Resource persons may be 
invited to participate in the programs as needed, with financing from the training budget.

4   
 
13.  Assumptions and risks. The government’s continued commitment to reform is a major 
risk. While it has already approved the establishment of the water cell, advancement of the 
reform may encounter delays in the government’s approval process. An effective regulatory 
framework  requires  higher  autonomy  for  water  utilities,  which  may  be  possible  only  with 
legislative changes. However, the government’s commitment is currently strong. For example, 
LGD  issued  a  circular  in  2009  to  municipalities  to  improve  their  financial  and  accounting 
systems, including establishment of a separate account for revenue from water supply and 
introduction of a double-entry bookkeeping system for water supply sections. This risk can be 
mitigated to a manageable level by engaging the government closely in TA implementation. 
While the government requested 4–5 years of ADB support, the TA will cover the initial 2 years 
to confirm the government’s renewed commitment. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $820,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV); and (ii) $250,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership Facility, 
and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart support in the form of (i) any 
relevant  documents,  data,  statistics,  information,  or  maps  that  the  government  has  at  its 
disposal; (ii) adequate number of qualified counterpart staff in the water cell, including their field 
per diem and field transportation; (iii) office accommodation and office equipment, including 
desks, chairs, and local communication (but excluding computers, printers, and photocopiers); 
(iv) logistical assistance for the workshops and seminars, including venue provision and sending 
invitations to participants; and (v) other in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing 
plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  The PSU under LGD will be the executing agency. It will appoint qualified counterpart 
staff to take the lead in supervising all tasks performed by the consultants and coordinating the 
activities with relevant organizations. A national steering committee (NSC) will be established to 
monitor TA implementation. The LGD secretary will chair the NSC, which will comprise senior 
representatives from the Planning Commission, Dhaka WASA, the Department of Public Health 
Engineering,  the  Economic  Relations  Division,  the  Finance  Division,  existing  regulatory 
commission(s), LGD, the Local Government Engineering Department, the Municipal Association 
of Bangladesh, and the PSU.11 The head of the PSU will be a member and the convener of the 
NSC.  The  NSC  will  meet  at  least  biannually  to  discuss  overall  TA  progress,  strengthen 
interministerial coordination, and provide policy guidance for TA implementation. Under the 
overall guidance of the NSC, the existing monitoring committee chaired by the LGD additional 
secretary will meet at least quarterly to discuss detailed progress of the TA. Progress will be 
regularly reported to the Water Supply and Sanitation Sub-Group of the Local Consultative 
Group.  
 
16.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  from  June  2013  to  June  2015.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 3. International expertise (15 person-months) will be 
obtained in the areas of financial regulation and water sector policy reform. National consultants 
(41  person-months)  will  have  expertise  in  water  sector  policy  reform,  financial  regulation, 
                                                
11 An existing NSC, which was previously established for Danida support to the PSU, will be used with necessary 
adjustments.

5 
institutional development, and legal issues. ADB will engage the consultants in accordance with 
its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). A team of 
consultants will be recruited through a firm under one package using the quality- and cost-based 
method of selection with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10. This ratio is justified due to the expertise 
and quality required in the assignment. A simplified technical proposal will be used for the 
selection of the consultant firm. In addition to the team described in Appendix 3, a few individual 
consultants may be engaged to address specific TA needs. Disbursement under the TA will be 
made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). Some equipment, such as computers and printers, will be procured 
using  the  shopping  method,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). All equipment, including software, purchased under the TA will be 
provided to the PSU after TA completion. ADB will undertake a TA review, in collaboration with 
LGD, at least twice a year during TA implementation. 
 
17.  The  consultants  will  assist  the  government  in  organizing  workshops  during  TA 
implementation. Consultation workshops with major water utilities and other stakeholders will be 
held to seek their inputs in the drafts and disseminate the final documents. The workshops will 
also serve as a venue to share good practices and lessons identified during TA implementation. 
The consultants will ensure coordination with related programs of other development partners, 
including those by Danida and the Water and Sanitation Program funded by the World Bank, to 
maximize complementarities and avoid duplication. Orientation training for counterpart staff in 
the water cell and other relevant officers in the PSU and LGD will be held within the first 2 
months. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $250,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Netherlands Trust Fund under the Water Financing Partnership 
Facility; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant 
basis, to the Government of Bangladesh for Establishing a Regulatory Framework for Urban 
Water Supply and Sanitation, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require about 56 person-months of consulting services: 
15 person-months international and 41 person-months national.  
 
2.  Team leader and financial regulation expert (international, 9 person-months). The 
expert  should  have  a  strong  background  in  finance,  with  a  master’s  degree  in  business 
administration and/or a professional designation such as chartered financial analyst, chartered 
accountant, or equivalent. The expert should be knowledgeable with the regulatory framework 
of a number of countries including developing countries in Asia, and have experience working 
on tariff-setting methodologies in developing countries. In collaboration with other experts, the 
expert will 
(i)  review current financial practices of major water utilities, including billing and 
collection systems, accounting, financial statements, inventory systems, and tariff 
setting; 
(ii)  draft  a  financial  management  regulation,  based  on  the  review  of  existing 
practices, including the billing and collection systems, accounting systems, and 
preparation of financial statements; 
(iii)  draft  tariff-setting  and  review  methodologies  that  are  implementable  in  the 
context of Bangladesh; 
(iv)  undertake  a  study  on  subsidies  for  water  utilities  for  capital  and  operating 
expenditures, and recommend an appropriate subsidy mechanism; 
(v)  assist  the  water  cell  in  disseminating  the  overall  regulatory  framework  and 
reporting requirements to major water utilities, particularly with respect to the 
financial management regulation and tariff setting and review methodologies; 
ensuring the submission of reports from them; and preparing a monitoring report 
in accordance with the approved procedures and requirements; 
(vi)  advise the government on international best practices for water sector regulation 
and provide specific guidance in the context of Bangladesh;  
(vii)  develop reporting requirements from water utilities to the water cell, including 
templates; 
(viii)  undertake consultation with stakeholders on draft rules, regulations, standards, 
and other TA outputs;  
(ix)  assist the government in applying the approved tariff-setting methodologies to 
actual cases of tariff adjustments (at least two cases); 
(x)  jointly work with the international water sector policy reform expert and other 
members in developing and implementing the capacity development program; 
take the lead on financial aspects of the program; 
(xi)  suggest legislative changes to make water utilities more financially autonomous 
to incentivize them to improve operating efficiency; 
(xii)  assess the progress and achievements of the TA and draft a road map for 
establishing a water economic regulatory commission (WERC); 
(xiii)  guide, supervise, and support the activities of other experts to undertake the 
defined activities and ensure quality of work; and 
(xiv)  ensure that all tasks of the terms of reference are performed on time and with 
satisfactory quality. 
 
3.  Deputy team leader and water supply sector reform specialist (national, 20 person-
months). The specialist should have an engineering background and experience working in 
urban water supply policy development and implementation; working experience in an urban

water utility is desirable. The specialist will support the team leader in managing overall TA 
implementation and assist the team leader in undertaking all tasks. The specialist will  
(i)  draft service standards and key performance indicators that are clearly defined 
and measurable, to be reported by the water utilities; 
(ii)  provide inputs in the institutional structure, mandates, staff requirements, and job 
descriptions and qualifications of the water cell and WERC; 
(iii)  assist the government in obtaining formal approval of the rules and standards 
drafted  under  the  TA,  including  preparation  of  summary  materials  and/or 
presentation in local language; 
(iv)  take the lead in undertaking consultation with stakeholders on the draft outputs of 
the TA; 
(v)  work with the water cell to communicate the overall regulatory framework and 
reporting requirements to major water utilities, ensure the submission of reports 
from them, and compile them into a monitoring report; 
(vi)  lead the work on drafting customer service standards with inputs from other 
experts; 
(vii)  establish the framework, including a database for monitoring performance of 
water utilities in accordance with the reporting requirements; 
(viii)  develop  and  implement  the  capacity  development  program,  including 
coordination with government agencies; 
(ix)  suggest  legislative  changes  to  make  water  utilities  more  autonomous  to 
incentivize them to improve operating efficiency; 
(x)  provide technical inputs in the draft road map for establishing the WERC; 
(xi)  ensure close coordination with the water cell, the Local Government Division, 
relevant development partners, and other stakeholders including members of the 
Water Supply and Sanitation Sub-Group of the Local Consultative Group; and 
(xii)  supervise and support other experts' activities under the guidance of the team 
leader. 
 
4.  Water  supply  sector  reform  expert  (international,  6  person-months).  The  expert 
should have an engineering background and experience in urban water supply policy reform 
and  monitoring  of  water  utilities.  The  expert  should  be  knowledgeable  of  the  regulatory 
framework  of  a  number  of  countries  including  developing  countries  in  Asia.  Under  the 
supervision of the team leader and deputy team leader, the expert will 
(i)  draft service standards and key performance indicators that are clearly defined 
and measurable, to be reported by the water utilities; 
(ii)  define  the  institutional  structure,  mandates,  staff  requirements,  and  job 
descriptions and qualifications of the water cell and WERC; 
(iii)  based on the approved organogram and staff requirements, assess capacity 
requirements  for  staff,  and  prepare  and  implement  a  capacity  development 
program for putting in place adequate capacity in the water cell focusing on 
technical  aspects;  and  co-lead  implementation  of  the  capacity  development 
program; 
(iv)  develop a monitoring framework for water utilities reflecting the service standards 
and  key  performance  indicators,  and  assist  the  water  cell  in  undertaking 
monitoring and producing reports; 
(v)  advise the government on international best practices for water sector regulation 
and provide specific guidance considering the context of Bangladesh, mainly 
from a technical viewpoint; 
(vi)  suggest  legislative  changes  to  make  water  utilities  more  autonomous  to 
incentivize them to improve operating efficiency; and

Appendix 3  11 
(vii)  work with other members in drafting a road map for establishing the WERC. 
 
5.  Financial  regulation  specialist (national, 13 person-months). The specialist should 
have a strong background in finance, with a master’s degree in business administration and/or a 
professional  designation  such  as  chartered  financial  analyst,  chartered  accountant,  or 
equivalent. Experience working in the urban water sector is desirable. Under the supervision of 
the team leader and deputy team leader, the specialist will 
(i)  review current financial practices of major water utilities, including billing and 
collection systems, accounting, financial statements, inventory systems, and tariff 
setting; 
(ii)  draft  a  financial  management  regulation,  based  on  the  review  of  existing 
practices,  including  the  billing  and  collection  systems,  accounting  systems, 
preparation of financial statements, and reporting requirements; 
(iii)  draft  tariff-setting  and  review  methodologies  that  are  implementable  in  the 
context of Bangladesh; 
(iv)  undertake  a  study  of  subsidies  to  water  utilities  for  capital  and  operating 
expenditures, and recommend an appropriate subsidy mechanism; 
(v)  assist the water cell in disseminating the financial management regulation and 
tariff-setting,  and  review  methodologies  to  key  stakeholders,  particularly  the 
major water utilities; 
(vi)  assist the team leader in developing and implementing the capacity development 
program with regard to financial aspects; 
(vii)  assist the government in applying the approved tariff-setting methodologies to 
actual cases of tariff adjustments (at least two cases); 
(viii)  suggest legislative changes to make water utilities more financially autonomous 
to incentivize them to improve operating efficiency; and 
(ix)  provide inputs in the draft road map for establishing the WERC. 
 
6.  Institutional  development  specialist  (national,  4  person-months).  The  specialist 
should  have  a  strong  background  in  institutional  analysis  and  development  as  well  as 
experience working in the urban water sector. Under the supervision of the team leader and 
deputy team leader, the specialist will 
(i)  provide inputs in the institutional structure, mandates, staff requirements, and job 
descriptions and qualifications of the water cell and WERC; 
(ii)  assess capacity requirements of the water cell staff in accordance with their 
mandates; and 
(iii)  coordinate with other members in developing and implementing the capacity 
development program. 
 
7.  Legal  specialist  (national,  4  person-months).  The  specialist  should  have  a  legal 
background  with  experience  in  drafting  laws,  rules,  and  regulations  in  Bangladesh.  The 
specialist should preferably have experience working in the urban water subsector. Under the 
supervision of the team leader and deputy team leader, the specialist will 
(i)  assess relevant laws, regulations, standards, and policies existing in Bangladesh 
in the water sector and make suggestions on how the autonomy of the water 
utilities can be strengthened and practiced; 
(ii)  review the draft rules and regulations prepared by other team members and 
ensure conformity with legal requirements; and  
(iii)  provide inputs, from a legal point of view, in the draft road map for establishing 
the WERC.

12  Appendix 3 
D.  Reporting 
 
8.  The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 1.5 months after commencing 
TA services, finalizing the approach, detailed work plan, and implementation schedule for the 
TA; (ii) an interim report within 5 months after commencing services, summarizing the progress 
made, draft rules and standards (except for those specified in the inception report that require 
more  time  for  preparation)  to  enable  regulatory  monitoring,  for  government  approval,  and 
proposed adjustments in the work plan and timeline of the TA; (iii) progress reports 9, 12, and 
15 months after commencing the services that will summarize TA progress, problems, and 
challenges; suggest ways to address any problems; and note major achievements and planned 
programs for the next quarter, particularly on the performance monitoring of major water utilities; 
the first progress report will include a detailed capacity development program such as course 
content, delivery format, expected participants, exposure visit program, and budget estimates, 
to be implemented under the TA; (iv) a draft final report 19 months after commencing the 
services that will summarize activities undertaken and results achieved, compare achievements 
with original targets, review problems encountered during implementation and propose actions 
to remedy those problems, and recommend future short- to medium-term programs including a 
road map for establishing the WERC; and (v) a final report 3 weeks after the final workshops 
and  receipt  of  comments  on  the  draft  final  report  from  the  government  and  the  Asian 
Development Bank.
